moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nf3 b6
1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nf3 b6 4. g3 Ba6 5. b3 Bb7 6. Bg2 Bb4+
comment: Black has forced a slight weakening of White's queen-side and now he tries to discoordinate White's pieces.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nf3 b6 4. g3 Ba6 5. b3 Bb7 6. Bg2 Bb4+ 7. Bd2 c5
comment: It seems a little unusual to allow Bxb4 cxb4 when Black gives up on some central control. What he gains is control of c3, so White can't play Nb1-c3 to control both e4 and d5.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nf3 b6 4. g3 Ba6 5. b3 Bb7 6. Bg2 Bb4+ 7. Bd2 c5 8. O-O O-O 9. Bxb4 cxb4 10. Qd3
1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nf3 b6 4. g3 Ba6 5. b3 Bb7 6. Bg2 Bb4+ 7. Bd2 c5 8. O-O O-O 9. Bxb4 cxb4 10. Qd3 d5
comment: Black doesn't worry about Pd5 blocking Bb7 forever. Since there's a Pc4 Black will have ...dxc4 to reopen the diagonal.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nf3 b6 4. g3 Ba6 5. b3 Bb7 6. Bg2 Bb4+ 7. Bd2 c5 8. O-O O-O 9. Bxb4 cxb4 10. Qd3 d5 11. Nbd2 Qe7 12. Rfc1 Nbd7 13. Ne5
comment: perhaps threatening cxd5 and Rc7 or Nc6, but as much as anything White is just moving forward into the gap and cramping Black as he goes. He might continue with f2-f4 to add another pawn to the central fight or e2-e4 to blast through the middle.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nf3 b6 4. g3 Ba6 5. b3 Bb7 6. Bg2 Bb4+ 7. Bd2 c5 8. O-O O-O 9. Bxb4 cxb4 10. Qd3 d5 11. Nbd2 Qe7 12. Rfc1 Nbd7 13. Ne5 Nxe5 14. dxe5 Nd7 15. cxd5
comment: White threatens d5-d6 to win Bb7.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nf3 b6 4. g3 Ba6 5. b3 Bb7 6. Bg2 Bb4+ 7. Bd2 c5 8. O-O O-O 9. Bxb4 cxb4 10. Qd3 d5 11. Nbd2 Qe7 12. Rfc1 Nbd7 13. Ne5 Nxe5 14. dxe5 Nd7 15. cxd5 exd5 16. f4 Nc5 17. Qd4 Ne6 18. Qf2 Rfc8
comment: I think Black has used this rook to clear f8 if he needs to retreat his knight (...Ne6-f8) .

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nf3 b6 4. g3 Ba6 5. b3 Bb7 6. Bg2 Bb4+ 7. Bd2 c5 8. O-O O-O 9. Bxb4 cxb4 10. Qd3 d5 11. Nbd2 Qe7 12. Rfc1 Nbd7 13. Ne5 Nxe5 14. dxe5 Nd7 15. cxd5 exd5 16. f4 Nc5 17. Qd4 Ne6 18. Qf2 Rfc8 19. f5 Nf8 20. Qd4 Rc5
comment: Black's queen-side coordination seems pretty good, but the possibility of f5-f6 to breech Black's king-side continues to give White the better chances to find a win. Incidentally, Pb4 is poison as long as Black has ...Rxc1+ to uncover a defense (Qe7 defends Pb4) .

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nf3 b6 4. g3 Ba6 5. b3 Bb7 6. Bg2 Bb4+ 7. Bd2 c5 8. O-O O-O 9. Bxb4 cxb4 10. Qd3 d5 11. Nbd2 Qe7 12. Rfc1 Nbd7 13. Ne5 Nxe5 14. dxe5 Nd7 15. cxd5 exd5 16. f4 Nc5 17. Qd4 Ne6 18. Qf2 Rfc8 19. f5 Nf8 20. Qd4 Rc5 21. Nf3 Rac8 22. Re1 Rc3
comment: If Black can get in ...Qc5 to force a simpler middlegame he would be fine.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nf3 b6 4. g3 Ba6 5. b3 Bb7 6. Bg2 Bb4+ 7. Bd2 c5 8. O-O O-O 9. Bxb4 cxb4 10. Qd3 d5 11. Nbd2 Qe7 12. Rfc1 Nbd7 13. Ne5 Nxe5 14. dxe5 Nd7 15. cxd5 exd5 16. f4 Nc5 17. Qd4 Ne6 18. Qf2 Rfc8 19. f5 Nf8 20. Qd4 Rc5 21. Nf3 Rac8 22. Re1 Rc3 23. Kh1 Re8 24. f6 gxf6 25. exf6 Qe4 26. Rad1 Re6 27. Rf1 Ba6
comment: Is Pe2 really the lynchpin of White's position? I doubt that capturing it is a significant to White as capturing Pd5 is to Black.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nf3 b6 4. g3 Ba6 5. b3 Bb7 6. Bg2 Bb4+ 7. Bd2 c5 8. O-O O-O 9. Bxb4 cxb4 10. Qd3 d5 11. Nbd2 Qe7 12. Rfc1 Nbd7 13. Ne5 Nxe5 14. dxe5 Nd7 15. cxd5 exd5 16. f4 Nc5 17. Qd4 Ne6 18. Qf2 Rfc8 19. f5 Nf8 20. Qd4 Rc5 21. Nf3 Rac8 22. Re1 Rc3 23. Kh1 Re8 24. f6 gxf6 25. exf6 Qe4 26. Rad1 Re6 27. Rf1 Ba6 28. Qxe4 Rxe4 29. Nd4 Re5 30. Nf5 Ng6
comment: I can't see that the knight does anything productive here.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nf3 b6 4. g3 Ba6 5. b3 Bb7 6. Bg2 Bb4+ 7. Bd2 c5 8. O-O O-O 9. Bxb4 cxb4 10. Qd3 d5 11. Nbd2 Qe7 12. Rfc1 Nbd7 13. Ne5 Nxe5 14. dxe5 Nd7 15. cxd5 exd5 16. f4 Nc5 17. Qd4 Ne6 18. Qf2 Rfc8 19. f5 Nf8 20. Qd4 Rc5 21. Nf3 Rac8 22. Re1 Rc3 23. Kh1 Re8 24. f6 gxf6 25. exf6 Qe4 26. Rad1 Re6 27. Rf1 Ba6 28. Qxe4 Rxe4 29. Nd4 Re5 30. Nf5 Ng6 31. Rxd5 Rxd5 32. Bxd5 Ne5 33. Nh6+ Kf8 34. Rf5 Re3 35. Rg5 Ng6
comment: At this point Pe2 is defenseless, but Ba6 is hopelessly out of play.

Nh6+ Kf8 34. Rf5 Re3 35. Rg5 Ng6 36. Bxf7 Rxe2 37. Bxg6 Bb7+ 38. Kg1 Rg2+ 39. Kf1 Rxh2 40. Bh5
comment: and the threat of Rg5-g8# can't be stopped
